\n
# 286\n
{Cambridge, Corpus Christi College 145, hand A, fols. 1r-210v: South English Legendary}\n
C14a1\n
429 195 N\n
{=NW Berks=}\n
{=Sample tagged: fols 63r-77r line 8; 82r line 11 - 92v line 18;\n
122r line 35 - 133r line 8 - Inventio Crucis, SS Quiriac, Brandan;\n
Barnabas, Theophilus, Alban, John the Baptist; James the Great,\n
Christopher, Martha, Oswald the King. Sections were chosen to\n
give some overlap with the 5 saints\' legends tagged from Laud Misc\n
108, hand A=}\n
{=Script - Anglicana=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=The punctuation is very simple. Apart from paragraph markers - noted as\n
\'para\' inside braces - which appear at the beginning of lines at\n
irregular intervals, marking new sections or sometimes changes of\n
speaker, there is only the punctus. This occurs regularly to mark the\n
half-line and very irregularly - apparently more or less randomly - at\n
the end of the line. The punctus is usually placed somewhere between\n
the baseline and half-way up the height of an average ascender, but as\n
there seems to be no difference in its function according to its height,\n
I mark it as an ordinary punctus . not as a raised punctus ^. It is not\n
always clear from microfilm whether end of line punctus are intended or\n
not: some are quite faint and may be pen resting marks. I have recorded\n
these if they seem clear to me and if they are in the expected position\n
not too far from the final letter of the final word in the line. The\n
decorative \'tail\' on final <e> also sometimes ends with an extra press\n
of the pen which could be intended as a punctus, but I have only\n
recorded it as such if the point is separate from the tail and/or done\n
with a separate movement. Each line begins with a littera notabilior,\n
these are marked as capitals with * and are normally formed as\n
capitals, except those litterae whose figurae are not always\n
differentiated between majuscule and minuscule. New sections begin\n
with a large decorated capital - noted after the word - followed by a\n
smaller capital letter. On the microfilm it looks as if the letter\n
immediately following the midline punctus is rubricated. I do not mark\n
these with * as they are not majuscule in shape, but the rubrication\n
is a useful guide to where missing or misplaced punctus should be\n
situated - I have noted any exceptions to the general rule=}\n
{~f63r~}\n
$/TOd_*y*E\n
{=Large initial *y=}\n
$holy/ajOd_HOL+Y $-ig/xs-ajOd_+Y\n
$rood/nOd_RODE\n
$/TOd_yE\n
$sweet/ajOd_SWETE\n
$tree/nOd_TRE[O]\n
{=O in words with final EO is habitually erased, I assume by a corrector\n
rather than the main scribe. This assumption is based on the fact that\n
other corrections are made in a hand and ink different from the main\n
scribe. I use [] to indicate where it happens as in d\'Evelyn and\n
Mill\'s EETS edition (d\'E&M). Midword the corrector has not usually\n
tried to alter EO. I take it therefore that EO was the spelling\n
intended by the original scribe; the brackets indicate merely that\n
the letter is not now wholly visible. This contrasts with the\n
correction of EO to E in the Ormulum where Orm was apparently\n
responsible both for the original spelling and for the removal\n
of the O. In the Ormulum therefore, I transcribe E<O< in such cases\n
rather than E[O]=}\n
{.}\n
$right/aj_RIzT\n

{=I assume that above the speaker is addressing the whole ship\'s\n
company - hence zE plural. But then he seems to change to yOU,\n
presumably addressing Brandan alone for 2 lines before changing\n
back to addressing everyone. Otherwise we would have to assume\n
a change from \'polite\' zE to \'familiar\' yOU and back again. The\n
text in Laud 108 makes the switch clear, but the added line that\n
does so spoils the rhyme scheme, so was presumably added to resolve\n
the ambiguity=}\n

$/P13OdM_HIm\n
$to/pr_TO\n
;_ROME\n
{=There is some textual corruption here. The other texts make it\n
clear that the Jews are afraid that the Emperor\'s cousin will\n
take Barnaby away from their custody and to Rome. But the syntax\n
here seems impossible to construe that way and the scribe presumably\n
misunderstood=}\n

{>para (*IN MEMORIA \\ ETerNA ERUnT IusTA \\ AB AUDACiONE \\ MALA NOn\n
TIME\\BUnT IN DIE NO\\UISSIMO.(>}\n
{=ins, in right hand margin - AUDACiONE for \'auditione\', cf. Vulgate\n
Ps. 111 v. 7=}\n
{\\}\n
$of/pr_*OF\n
$evil/aj<pr_UUEL\n
$hear/vn<pr_VR+InNGE $/vn<pr_+InNGE\n
{=sic - an odd spelling for this scribe and there could perhaps be\n
some textual corruption here. Palaeographically the reading could\n
be VRNInGE or VRUInGE but these make no sense and the required\n
meaning is supplied by the Latin \'auditione\' which itself is\n
corrupt - AUDACiONE - in this version=}\n
$on{t}/pr_A+\n
$doomsday/n<pr_+DOM+ES+DAY $/Gn-k_+ES+ $day/n<pr-k_+DAY\n
{.}\n
$/neg-v(>nothingav)_NE+\n
$shall/vps13_+SSEL\n

\n
# 272\n
{Cambridge, Corpus Christi College 402, fols. 1r-117: Ancrene Wisse}\n
C13b?\n
352 275 N\n
{=S Salop=}\n
{=Sample tagged: fols. 1r-32r=}\n
{=Script - early Textura semi-quadrata=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=The scribe does not like to leave gaps at the end of lines. He does\n
sometimes split words to avoid this, but is much less inclined to do\n
it than most other scribes. Instead he occasionally uses line-fillers\n
such as tiny diagonal strokes, but more often enlarges by some means\n
the final letter of the line. He makes extended cross strokes on final\n
E or T (not noted) he capitalises and extends N, R and F (noted as *N,\n
*R and *F, and he often uses an extended S which lies on its back.\n
It is not like his usual capital S, so I have not recorded it as *S,\n
but as S with a separate note indicating it is a line-filler type of S.\n
The microfilm I have used is very faint and the details noted by\n
Tolkien (1962) are often not visible on the film=}\n
{~f1r~}\n
{>)(*LIBER *OCTAUUS()>}\n
{=ins, in top margin in a later hand=}\n
{>)(*LIBER ECCLesIE *SanCtI *IACOBI DE WYGEMOR . QUEm *IOHannES *PURCEL\n
DEDIT \\ EIDEm ECCLesIE AD INSTANCIAm FRatrIS *WALTerI DE *LODEL~\n
SENIORIS TUnC PreCEnTORIS , \\ *SIQu^IS DiCtuM LIBRUm ALIENAUerIT A\n
PreDiCtA ECClesiA . UeL TITULUm HUnC MALICiOSE \\ DELEUerIT .\' ANATHEMA\n
SIT . *AMen . FIAT . FIAT . FIAT . *AME*N .()}\n
{=ins, in lower margin in a late C13 hand, saying that the book\n
was given to the House of Augustian Canons at Wigmore by John Purcel on\n
the instigation of Brother Walter of Ludlow, senior precentor. The\n
Purcels were of S. Salop. JP late C13 held land at Norbury nr. Bishop\'s\n
Castle and at Diddlebury nr. Ludlow=}\n
{=Rubricated text begins=}\n

{=Rubricated text ends. Note that this title in English is written\n
beside the opening Latin in red, taking up three half-lines and\n
one word\'s space. It is illegible on microfilm, though just\n
visible on the facsimile page in the Tolkien (1962) edition=}\n

DIFFERERNCIE TOTIDEM REGULARum . *DE RECTO THEOLO\\GICO SERMO NOBIS EST .\n
CUIus REGULE DUE SUNT . *VNA CIRCA \\ CORDIS DIRECTIONEM . *ALTERA\n
UERSATUR C^IrCA EXETERIORUM \\ RECTIFICATIONEM . *RECTI DILIGUNT TE .(}\n

GENUISTI ETerNI LUMINIS CLARITATEM . *GAUDE MATER . GAUDE SanCtA DEI\n
GENETr^IX U^IrGO TU SOLA MATER \\ INNUPTA TE LAUDAT OMNIS FILII TUI\n
CREATURA GENITr^ICEM \\ LUCIS . SIS Pro NOBis PIA INTerUENTr^IX . Verset.\n

$to/pr+H_TO\n
$unmae:rehae:lu?/n<pr_HUN+MERE-HEILE $un-?/xp-n_HUN+ $hae:lu/n<pr-k_-HEILE\n
{=Tolkien (1962) reads HIMMERE, but makes no suggestion as to origins\n
or meaning. The minims can be plausibly split as I read it here and it\n
would then be easy to adopt the reading suggested in MED of unmae:re.\n
But there is likely to be some corruption as Cleopatra also has\n
HIMMERE or HUNMERE HEALE while N and T leave it out. Neither the\n
Corpus scribe nor the Cleopatra scribe have HUN- for UN- elsewhere,\n
though excresent H- forms are known in other EME texts and in the SWML\n
especially in Digby 86. It could also possibly be read as UNIUERE for\n
UNFERE meaning "sick", "diseased", "harmful". Millett (2005) emends to\n
HINENE HULEN on the basis of that the scriptural passage analysed here\n
should include the "tabernacula pastorum". This may very well be a satisfactory\n
textual emendation and possibly what was intended by the author. It does\n
not, however, help us to work out what the Corpus scribe thought he was\n
writing here=}\n
{.}\n
$/P13OiF_HIRE\n
{\\}\n

# 155\n
{Cambridge, Corpus Christi College 444, fols. 1r-81r: Genesis and Exodus}\n
C14a1\n
582 312 E\n
{=W Norfolk=}\n
{=Sample tagged: fols. 1r-41r=}\n
{=Script - Textura semi-quadrata=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=The scribe has an unusual form of wynn with an open top. Punctuation\n
is confined to punctus at the end of each verse line, occasionally\n
omitted, and punctus mid-line to divide lists. First letters of lines\n
are marked with red, but only those with majuscule form are here\n
preceded with an asterisk to indicate a capital=}\n
{~f1r~}\n
{>)(*SAPIT QUI *SUSCEPIT( \\ *RIC *SOUTHWELL)>}\n
{=ins, in top margin in a 16th-century hand=}\n
$man/indef_*M*AN\n
{=Four-line red initial *M=}\n

\'_*IOBAL\n
$/P13GM-Gn_-IS\n
$brother/n_BROdER\n
{=Arngart (1968) has a complicated explaination that the previous instance of \n
*IOBAL four line\'s up is for "Jabal" and this one (spelled the same and \n
therefore \'mixed together\') is for "Jubal", his brother. Both Jabal and \n
Jubal were certainly brothers, both sons of Lamech and Adah. But rather \n
than assuming confusion of the names it seems better to take it that Jubal is not \n
actually named here but that this construction simply refers to "Jabal\'s\n
brother" via the construction "Jabal-is brother"=}\n
$song/nOd_SONG\n

$by/pr<_BI\n
{=Letter subpuncted and then erased=}\n
$ae:ht/nOd{rh}_AGT\n
{=This is awkward as to word order, but works most simply as: "whoever holds\n
his property by him" i.e. "in his possession". Arngart (1968) takes HIS\n
to be "is" but this is difficult with ALT because he has to supply both\n
a personal pronoun and relative: "whoever he is that holds etc".\n
Morris\'s (1874) solution is even more awkward with HIS as "them" and\n
BI-AGT as "behoveth"=}   \n
{\\}\n
{>.*G.>}\n

out and examples given of their use. Because there is no syntactic\n
context some of the tags may be debatable=}\n

{.}\n
{=Rest of folio is blank=}\n
{~f115r~}\n
{=Poema Morale is prefaced by two lines from Sinners Beware. It is\n
formatted in the usual long-line rhyming couplets. This version lacks\n
70 lines of the original as evidenced by the Trinity text, the fullest\n
of the surviving versions. It contains two further couplets - apart\n
from the first - that do not occur in the other versions. Paues\n
(1907:225) therefore considers that the exemplar from which this was\n
copied (or a precursor) may  have been written down from memory. This\n
version lacks the midline punctus found in most of the other versions=}\n
$/TG_>y>E\n
{=Space left for two-line initial, not carried out. Thorn supplied from\n
guide letter in left margin=}\n

$death/n<pr_DIAyE\n
{=Paues reads DRAyE and emends to DEAyE but the reading is certainly\n
DIAyE. The small dot beside the I that Paues takes to be the limb of R\n
is actually the beginning of the approach stroke of A. Moreover, an R\n
formed by a minim and a limb would be the wrong shape - this scribe\n
habitually uses the 2-shaped R after the rounded bow of D=}\n

{=There is a line of Latin, probably in the same hand, beneath the final\n
line of the PM. It is too faint in the reproduction to read but may\n

# 265\n
{Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College 52/29, fol. 43r: Creed, Pater Noster, Ave Maria, In manus tuas}\n
C13\n
0 0 N\n
{=Not placed=}\n
{=Sample represents all the text in English in this hand=}\n
{=Script - 13th century book hand influenced by documentary script=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=Y and y identical and thorn-like - here realised as Y. W is very\n
idiosyncratic being formed by a single diagonal first stroke with a\n
3-shaped broken stroke placed against it - almost like two Vs stacked\n
rather than properly ligatured. Sometimes punctus appear on either\n
side of Tironian symbol for \'and\'. These are regarded as part of the\n
symbol and are not recorded separately as punctuation marks=}\n
{~f43r~}\n
{=English texts begin in column b beneath preceding Latin \'Summa qui\n
dicitur speculum in morum\'=}\n
{>(\'*CREDO.\'(>}\n
{=ins, in right hand margin with lines connecting to the first and last\n
line of the text of the creed=}\n
{para}\n

\n
# 276\n
{Cambridge, Gonville and Caius 234/120, pp. 1-185: extracts from Ancrene Riwle}\n
C13b1\n
378 275 N\n
{=NW Worcs=}\n
{=Sample tagged: pp. 1-59=}\n
{Script - an idiosyncratic mixed book hand with cursive features\n
including some suggesting Anglicana e.g. long <r> and 8-shaped <g>=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=Thorn and wynn are not distinguished in this hand, both lacking\n
ascenders. Following my usual practice, I have however transcribed\n
them as separate letters according to context; otherwise reading\n
becomes very confused. In the first few pages W and V are used for [w]\n
alongside wynn. But wynn is mostly regularised (with a few exceptions)\n
after p. 4. There is also some difficulty in separating the usage of CC,\n
CT and TT because the scribe tends to use the same ligature for all\n
three, though there are no examples of CC in the part so far\n
tagged. I have not normalised as Wilson (1954) does in his EETS edition, but\n
have cT where the ligature is clearly made for TT. The use of lower\n
case c is so as to distinguish this purely orthographic usage from\n
genuine CT for [kt] and CT for [xt] in hands where OE -ht words have CT\n
as a variant. In these cases I transcribe CT. Cf. also Layamon A, hand\n
B who uses a similar ligature for all three uses as well as in [xt]\n
contexts. Some parts of p. 1 are difficult to read on film because of\n
discolouration. For these parts I have had to rely on the EETS edition\n
which seems extremely accurate judging by the text as a whole=}\n
{~p1~}\n
{>(\'*CONTra *IRAM\'(>}\n
{=ins, to the right hand part of the first line of text=}\n

$word/npl<pr_VOR\\D+ES $/pln<pr_+ES\n
{=Wilson (1954) reads BORDES which makes no sense. \'words\' is required as in\n
the other texts. The initial letter is rather upright for a \'V\' but\n
the lobe seems narrower at the foot than the scribe\'s usual \'B\' and\n
the ascender a little short. I believe a \'V\' was certainly intended.\n
The scribe uses \'V\' for [w] frequently in the early pages and for VORD\n
itself on p 2 line 1=}\n
{.\'}\n

{=Repeated in error. Wilson (1954) reads wOCH yOCH but this is unnecessary\n
complication. The words (apart from the correction in the first) are\n
identically written and although it is possible to read wOCH yOCH (or\n
yOCH wOCH) presumably taking yOCH as a form of "though" (for which this\n
scribe usually writes yACH) the true text (cf. Corpus and the\n

$undergitan/vi_UNDER+yET+EN $under-/xp-v_UNDER+ $/vi_+EN\n
{=Wilson (1954) reads UNDERwETEN. The figura is identical whether y or w was\n
intended. The required by the text is OE undergitan and in this\n
scribe\'s system G would be expected for [j]. He has perhaps been misled\n
by yogh or possibly Y in his exemplar. What he intended by his\n
interchangeable y-w figura is not certain, but cf. two parallel cases:\n
p. 29 where the scribe writes CHIRCyARD (or wARD) for "churchyard" and\n
p. 45 where he writes yATTE or wATTE for "gate"=}\n

$forculien/vpspK2_FOR+CUL+IINDE $for-/xp-v_FOR+ $/vpspK2_+IINDE\n
{="blackened". Wilson (1954) reads FORTULIINDE. The C is somewhat carelessly\n
formed, but need not be read as T. The scribe\'s Ts are usually\n
distinct with the crossbar of the T coming strongly across both to\n
left and right of the upright while the crossbar of C is only to the\n
right. There are, however, intermediate cases of both letters, of\n
which this is one. Cf. C in CHILD p. 23 line 3 from foot=}\n
{\\}\n

$twe:onship?/n<pr_TwEN+SHI\\PE $-ship/xs-n<pr_+SHI\\PE\n
{=Wilson (1954) reads CwENSHIPE but the first letter is a clear T. The \'correct\'\n
textual reading is CwEDSHIPE (cf. Corpus etc) but CwENSHIPE, apart from\n
not being a recorded word, could only mean "the state of being a queen\n
or a woman" and makes no sense at all in context. TwENSHIPE is also\n
not recorded but could make some sense if it were taken as being formed\n
from OE twe:on "doubt" or if it were connected with twa twegen with a\n
similar sense suggesting duplicity=}\n

$or/cj_OdER\n
$/P11N_ICH\n
$have/vps11_BABBE\n
{=sic - Scribes normally form \'h\' and \'b\' similarly with two strokes, an\n
ascender followed by a lobe drawn from some point on the ascender and\n
curving out and down. In the case of \'b\' it ideally meets the foot of\n
the ascender at the baseline. In the case of \'h\' it ideally meets the\n
baseline to the right of the ascender, sometimes descending below it and\n
often curving further inwards. Scribal mistaking of <h> and <b> where\n
intended \'h\' has a short limb and/or where it cuts in too much and hits\n
the ascender (forming a <b>-like lobe) is very common indeed.\n
Conversely, where a \'b\' is formed somewhat loosely and the lobe does not\n
properly meet the ascender it can easily be read as \'h\'. One then has to\n
judge whether the figura should be read as the littera that it\n
superficially looks like or as what was \'intended\'. The G scribe himself\n
differentiates these letters clearly; indeed he uses a different stroke\n
patterns to form them  \'h\' he forms traditionally with two strokes; \'b\'\n
he forms in a single stroke curving the lobe up from the bottom of the\n
ascender. It is often open at the top, failing to meet the ascender\n
further up.  The G scribe\'s miswriting of \'b\' for \'h\' was presumably\n
triggered by a \'b\'-like \'h\' in his exemplar, the error unnoticed because\n
the G scribe was writing at speed=}\n
$be/vSpp_I+BEO+N $ge-/xp-vpp_I+ $/vSpp[V]_+N\n

{=Wilson (1954) reads CHIRCwARD. Again, formally the figura could be either. The\n
text requires "churchyard" not "churchward(en)" and we would expect +GARD\n
in this scribe\'s system. He presumably was copying from a system which\n
used yogh or Y for [j] . cf. p 10 UNDERyETEN -wETEN and p. 45 yATTE\n
wATTE "gate"=}\n

{=Final D looks superficially as if it could be edh. But in this part of\n
the manuscript the scribe makes edh with a comma-shaped stroke starting\n
near the top of D and finishing at the level of the top of the lobe.\n
(From p. 46 he occasionally uses an S-shaped stroke to the\n
ascender instead of his usual comma-shaped stroke. The S-shape becomes\n
more frequent near the end of the manuscript.) Here, the hairline\n
stroke from the right of the ascender, and cutting across it to be\n
visible fractionally to the left, was almost certainly made before\n
the back of the D was drawn down. The first C-shaped stroke of the D\n
is made, the scribe lifts or lightens the pen somewhat and takes it up to\n
the top ready to make the down stroke to finish the letter. This\n
looping movement of the pen is usually made in the air but is not always\n
completely off the parchment as it is sometimes visible as a hairline\n
\'pot hook\' to the right of the main down stroke of the D. The scribe seems\n
sometimes not to bring the down stroke directly down from the circular\n
movement but to reposition the pen first, leaving a hairline trace near\n
the top of the D=}\n
{.}\n
$&/cj_&\n
$all/aj_AL\n

$8/qoaj_>E>AHTUyE\n
{=Wilson (1954) reads AHTUyE and takes the E interlined above the E of the\n
previous yE to be one of the scribe\'s repeated interlineations. But\n
the E of yE is not ill-formed and needs no correction and the scribe\n
sometimes places his interlineations back from the word they should go\n
with; cf. interlined H in the last line of p 26=}\n
$thing/n_yING\n

$he:reword/n<pr_HERE+wORD $word/n<pr-k_+wORD\n
{=Final D looks superficially as if it could be edh. But in this part of\n
the manuscript the scribe makes edh with a comma-shaped stroke starting\n
near the top of D and finishing at the level of the top of\n
the lobe. (From p. 46 he occasionally uses an S-shaped stroke to the\n
ascender instead of his usual comma-shaped stroke. The S-shape becomes\n
more frequent near the end of the manuscript.) Here, the hairline\n
stroke is part of stroke forming the back of D - see the first note\n
to towarplen above=}\n
{.\'}\n
